turns.content: Could you share some famous persons who have taken these programmes before and their achievement, mainly on art and history.

Certainly! Here are a few examples of notable individuals who have pursued graduate degrees in art and history related to scuba diving and their achievements:

* Dr. Guillermo de Anda, a Mexican archaeologist who completed a Ph.D. in underwater archaeology at Texas A&M University. He is known for his work in the exploration and preservation of underwater caves in the Yucatan Peninsula, including the discovery of the largest underwater cave system in the world.
* Dr. Franck Goddio, a French underwater archaeologist who completed a Ph.D. in maritime archaeology at the Sorbonne University. He is known for his discoveries of ancient shipwrecks and submerged cities, including the cities of Thonis-Heracleion and Canopus in Egypt.
* Dr. Pilar Luna Erreguerena, a Mexican art historian who completed a Ph.D. in art history with a focus on underwater archaeology at Texas A&M University. She is known for her research on the art and iconography of Mesoamerican cultures, as well as her work in the preservation of underwater cultural heritage in Mexico.
* Dr. Lucy Blue, a British maritime archaeologist who completed a Ph.D. in archaeology at the University of Southampton. She is known for her research on the archaeology of shipwrecks and maritime trade, as well as her work in the field of public engagement and outreach in archaeology.
* Dr. Marcos Martinón-Torres, a Spanish archaeometallurgist who completed a Ph.D. in archaeology with a focus on metallurgy and technology at the University of Oxford. He is known for his research on the technology and production of metal objects in ancient cultures, as well as his work in the preservation and conservation of archaeological materials.

These individuals have made significant contributions to the fields of art, history, and archaeology through their research and discoveries. They serve as examples of the opportunities and achievements that can be pursued with advanced degrees in these fields.
What should the applicant do to make her stand out in the application in these art and history programmes? She has solid experience on scuba diving and has done some field investigation in China.

If an applicant has solid experience in scuba diving and has conducted field investigations in China, they could highlight these experiences in their application to make them stand out. Here are a few tips on how to do so:

1. Emphasize your relevant experience: When writing your application essay or statement of purpose, be sure to emphasize how your scuba diving and field investigation experiences have prepared you for graduate study in art or history related to scuba diving. Discuss specific skills or knowledge you have gained through these experiences that you believe will be valuable in the program.
2. Showcase your research skills: If you have conducted field investigations in China, be sure to highlight your research skills in your application. Discuss your research methods, data analysis techniques, and any findings you may have uncovered. This will demonstrate your ability to conduct independent research, a skill that is highly valued in graduate programs.
3. Provide examples of your work: If you have any publications, presentations, or other examples of your work related to scuba diving or field investigations, include them in your application. This will give the admissions committee a tangible example of your skills and accomplishments.
4. Connect your experiences to the program: Make sure to tie your experiences in scuba diving and field investigations to the specific program you are applying to. Research the faculty and courses offered in the program and discuss how your experiences align with their research interests or course offerings.
5. Get strong letters of recommendation: Letters of recommendation from professors or supervisors who can speak to your relevant experience and skills can greatly strengthen your application. Be sure to choose recommenders who are familiar with your work in scuba diving and field investigations, and who can speak to your potential as a graduate student in art or history related to these fields.

By highlighting their relevant experience, research skills, and connections to the program, an applicant with a background in scuba diving and field investigations can make a strong case for their admission to graduate programs in art and history related to these fields.
